title: Cruise Performance (CPL Only)

questions.question: What is the purpose of flying for maximum range?
questions.answer: Flying the furthest distance possible with the fuel carried.

questions.question: Although carrying more fuel may extend your range, what is the negative aspect of doing so?
questions.answer: More fuel carried means greater weight, which means more power required to stay airborne, which means higher fuel burn.

questions.question: Range flying means using the __________ and __________ in the most efficient way possible.
questions.answer: Engine. Airframe.

questions.question: What are the four factors which increase or decrease range?
questions.answer: All Up Weight (AUW). Air tempture/density. Wind direction. Aircraft configuration.

questions.question: Lower AUW means a (greater/smaller) range).
questions.answer: Greater.

questions.question: Headwind (increases/decreases) range. Tailwind (increases/decreases) range.
questions.answer: Decreases. Increases.

questions.question: Warmer air (increases/decreases) range. Why?
questions.answer: Decreases. More power is required to maintain the same amount of lift in warm air, compared to cooler air.

questions.question: What are three aspects of airframe configuration that can impact range? In which configuration does each increase range?
questions.answer: Flaps, retracted. Undercarriage, retracted. Cowl gills, closed.

questions.question: For an airframe with an adjustable pitch propellor, different settings of __________ and __________ can increase or decrease range. Generally a combination of (high/low) __________ and (high/low) __________ increase range.
questions.answer: Manifold pressure. RPM. High manifold pressure. Low RPM.

questions.question: Correctly setting the __________ can have a significant effect on power, fuel flow, and efficiency. This procedure is called __________.
questions.answer: Mixture. Leaning.

questions.question: In most cases, when is leaning not permitted?
questions.answer: When using more than 81% power.

questions.question: Give the definition of Specific Range.
questions.answer: Distance travelled per unit of fuel burned.

questions.question: What are the two types of Specific Range? Give the definition of each.
questions.answer: Specific Air Range (SAR), air nautical miles travelled per unit of fuel burned. Specific Ground Range (SGR), ground nautical miles travelled per unit of fuel burned.

questions.question: What is the equation for determining SAR?
questions.answer: SAR = TAS / fuel flow.

questions.question: What is the equation for determining SGR?
questions.answer: SGR = GS / fuel flow.

questions.question: Best Specific Air range means ____________________, the unit for which is _____. It means we want the best ratio of (TAS/GS) to _____.
questions.answer: The greatest air nautical miles for a given amount of fuel. anmpg. TAS. Fuel flow.

questions.question: Because the fuel flow for a given engine/propellor combination depends on power, we require the most efficient _____ to _____ ratio.
questions.answer: TAS. Power.

questions.question: What is the Long Range Cruise Speed?
questions.answer: A recommended range speed for many aircraft, which is often slightly higher than the 'best range' speed.

questions.question: What are two reasons given for using Long Range Cruise Speed?
questions.answer: A significant saving in time can be obtained for a relatively small increase in fuel burn (eg. 5% saving in time for an extra 1% of fuel used). It can also improve aircraft handling compared to flying at 'best range' speed.

questions.question: Best Specific Ground Range means ____________________, the unit for which is _____. It means we want the best ratio of (TAS/GS) to _____.
questions.answer: The greatest ground nautical miles for a given amount of fuel. gnmpg. GS. Fuel flow.

questions.question: Calculate the SAR for a TAS of 120kt and a fuel flow of 11.8 US gal/hour.
questions.answer: 10.16 anm/US gal.

questions.question: Calculate the SGR for a TAS of 135kt, a 25kt tailwind, and fuel flow of 12.5 US gal/hour.
questions.answer: 12.8 gnm/US gal.

questions.question: What does flying for Maximum Endurance mean?
questions.answer: Remaining airborne as long as possible for a given amount of fuel.

questions.question: What is a common situation where you might configure the aircraft to fly for maximum endurance?
questions.answer: While holding.

questions.question: To fly for maximum endurance, we want to use the smallest amount of __________ required to remain airborne.
questions.answer: Fuel, or power.

questions.question: The _______________ is used to determine the speed and __________ which, for a given __________, provide the minimum __________ and maximum range.
questions.answer: Cruise Performance Chart. Altitude. All Up Weight (AUW). Fuel burn.

questions.question: Minimum flight time means ____________________.
questions.answer: Flying from one point to anther over the shortest time possible.

questions.question: Flying for minimum flight time is at the highest _____ in nil wind conditions, or _____ if there is a wind component.
questions.answer: TAS. GS.
